repository.corpname: The New York Preservation Archive Project

positionDescription.head: Preservation History Database
positionDescription.part: We are constantly updating this educational resource and need skilled writers, editors, and knowledgable professionals to research, write, review, and fact-check both new and existing entries.

positionDescription.head: Oral Histories
positionDescription.experienceRequired: interviewing, research, video editing, formatting interview materials
positionDescription.part: There are many opportunities to become involved in ongoing or past oral history projects. Individuals with the necessary skills and background knowledge can also be paired with preservationists to interview them and document their stories.

positionDescription.head: Archives and Collections
positionDescription.part: While we are not a permanent collecting institution, we maintain relationships with libraries and archives across the city, and work to ensure collections find a proper home. In certain circumstances, we are able to accept and house collections in our offices. Volunteers are essential in this process.

community_archives.description: The New York Preservation Archive Project is a not-for-profit organization dedicated to documenting, preserving, and celebrating the history of historic preservation in New York City. Recognizing the instructive and inspirational importance of this history to the continued health, success and growth of preservation in our City, the Archive Project hopes to bring these stories to light through public programs, oral histories, and providing access to information. The Archive Project is devoted to celebrating neglected narratives of New York City historic preservation using the archives that hold these stories.
community_archives.context: The New York Preservation Archive Project was founded because insufficient effort was being devoted to saving preservationâ€™s own history; memories were frequently lost; lessons from campaign victories and defeats were quickly forgotten; and noteworthy topics in this history were often overlooked. To reverse this tide of loss and capture this endangered record, the Archive Project conducts oral histories to record the memories of those who made preservation history and makes transcripts available here. The Archive Project also maintains a Preservation History Database, with key information on people, places, organizations, and public policy significant to the historic preservation in New York City.
